@lolyu can you state the purpose of the test in the pr comments? Seems that the ToR is correct sending the IO to uplink (tunnel routes) when server facing link is down. Are we specifically testing packet should be dropped without tunnel routes? Or should we verify that the packets were dropped by peer after exiting tunnel?

> @lolyu can you state the purpose of the test in the pr comments? Seems that the ToR is correct sending the IO to uplink (tunnel routes) when server facing link is down. Are we specifically testing packet should be dropped without tunnel routes? Or should we verify that the packets were dropped by peer after exiting tunnel?

Hi @yxieca, updated the PR description. Yes, this case is to validate the packet drop when egress port is down, so on dualtor-aa, we should enforce the same test steps to test the drop without the tunnel routes

Hi @Pterosaur,
I think we need to rework on how the tests verify the number of MSG per second capture by the tool.

I see an issue with the tests Msg/s verification
For example, this is the failure from one run of test_hft_port_counters

> Failed: Average Msg/s 77.97 is outside expected range: 85.00 - 115.00. 
> Individual values: [0.0, 0.0, 233.9, 233.9, 0.0, 0.0]

The problem is that the test configures SONiC to poll counters every 10ms (expecting 100 Msg/s), but HFT batches approximately 2339 messages before sending each report. 

If HFT polls correctly at 10ms intervals but batches 2339 messages per report:

- Time to accumulate: 2339 messages × 10ms = ~23.39 seconds of polling
- Transmission burst: Sending 2339 messages over ~10 seconds = 233.9 Msg/s 

The observed pattern [0.0, 0.0, 233.9, 233.9, 0.0, 0.0] matches this behavior:
- Reports during accumulation: 0.0 Msg/s (buffering, not sending)
- Reports during transmission: 233.9 Msg/s (burst of 2339 messages)

The test averages these values (77.97 Msg/s) which doesn't account for the batching cycle. HFT may be polling at the correct 10ms frequency, but the validation logic expects continuous streaming rather than batch-and-send behavior.

The purpose of this PR is in some weaker CPU setup, after fixture `setUp` done, the route is not in "active" state immediately, need wait a few seconds, which will affect traffic test. So I add a route status check before traffic test in this PR.
But in the community KVM testbed, the route is always in `inactive` state and traffic test is skipped in KVM. So the case can pass in community
```
vxlan/test_vxlan_bfd_tsa.py:
 skip_traffic_test:
 reason: "Skip traffic test for KVM testbed"
 conditions:
 - "asic_type in ['vs']"
```
When run the case with my PR in community KVM testbed, my PR will check the route status, if it is not "active", it will fail case. But the route is always `inactive` in KVM setup, so the PR checker fail.

```
bgp_events.py
dhcp-relay_events.py
event_utils.py
eventd_events.py
host_events.py
run_events_test.py
swss_events.py
```
The change I am proposing only skips `swss_events.py` which is the only one that uses `pfcwd`. Perhaps arista could look into creating separate test cases for each of these event types, but I personally am of the opinion that skipping the entire test case is too aggressive the way the test is written today.

> @ZhaohuiS , @StormLiangMS , is this ready for merge? do we have test results for all platforms?
> 
> @prabhataravind , can we ensure this test is running on SS SKUs

hi @prsunny We have only implemented the test for the Broadcom platform. Other platforms should have similar mechanisms for ECMP offset configuration, but since we have limited knowledge in those areas, Cisco and Mellanox may need to implement their respective parts. To avoid conflicts, we separated the implementation into PI and PD layers. This way, adding support for other platforms does not require modifying the PI code, which defines the test procedure and methodology — only the PD code needs to be updated to provide the platform-specific method for modifying the ECMP offset.
